qa_pairs.question: What is the significance of the transition from Mardani H. Maming to Akbar Buchari as chairman, and how does this relate to the historical leadership of HIPMI?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The transition from Mardani H. Maming to Akbar Buchari as chairman of HIPMI occurred in 2022, marking the formal succession of leadership within the organization.<cite>[S8][S9]</cite></statement> <statement>This transition reflects HIPMI's historical pattern of being led by prominent entrepreneurs, as seen in the list of past chairmen, including figures like Aburizal Bakrie and Sandiaga Salahuddin Uno, which underscores the organization's focus on influential leadership to drive youth entrepreneurship.<cite>[S27][S28][S32]</cite></statement>
qa_pairs.chunk:
Passage 1:
[S1] Indonesian Young Entrepreneur Association


# Indonesian Young Entrepreneur Association



**The Indonesian Young Entrepreneurs Association** (Indonesian: Himpunan Pengusaha Muda Indonesia) abbreviated as **HIPMI**, is an independent, non-partisan organization of young Indonesian entrepreneurs engaged in the economic sector. [S2] The organization was founded on June 10, 1972, by several national entrepreneurs including Drs. [S3] Abdul Latief, Ir. [S4] Siswono Yudo Husodo, Teuku Sjahrul, Datuk Hakim Thantawi, Badar Tando, Drs. [S5] Rudy Kairupan, Irawan Djajaatmadja, SH, Hari Sjamsudin Mangaan, Pontjo Sutowo, and Ir. [S6] Mahdi Diah. [S7] The establishment of this organization was driven by the spirit of fostering entrepreneurship among the youth. [S8] On November 23, 2022, Akbar Buchari was elected as the Chairman of the Indonesian Young Entrepreneurs Association (term 2022–2025), succeeding the previous chairman, Mardani H. [S9] Maming. [S10] ## Organizational Structure

The organizational structure of HIPMI exists at both the central and regional levels. [S11] HIPMI has established a Central Executive Board (BPP) headquartered in the capital city, Regional Executive Boards based in the provincial capitals, and Branch Executive Boards based in the regency/city capitals. [S12] To date, HIPMI has a presence in 37 provinces in Indonesia and comprises 354 Branch Executive Boards. [S13] In line with regional autonomy and expansion, HIPMI continues to grow to ensure representation throughout Indonesia. [S14] ## Membership

The organization's regulations establish two types of membership. [S15] Regular Members are those aged 17 – 40 years. [S16] Those who have surpassed the age of 41 are granted the status of Extraordinary Members, commonly referred to as Seniors. [S17] Membership is open to anyone who owns a business. [S18] ## HIPMI University (HIPMI PT)

HIPMI University, established on August 21, 2006, is an autonomous organization initiated by Erwin Aksa, Raja Sapta Oktohari, and Bahlil Lahadalia. [S19] The organization was first inaugurated by Jusuf Kalla, the Vice President of the Republic of Indonesia, and Erwin Aksa, Chairman of HIPMI for the 2008–2011 period. [S20] As its name suggests, HIPMI PT accepts members who are still undergraduate, master's, and doctoral students. [S21] With the presence of HIPMI PT, it is hoped that students can create job opportunities rather than just seeking employment. [S22] HIPMI initiated this organization due to the high unemployment rate in Indonesia. [S23] The organization observed that a significant portion of the unemployed were educated individuals. [S24] Therefore, university students are trained to become Economic Heroes who can improve the quality of human resources mentally, create jobs, and develop businesses effectively. [S25] The types of businesses run by HIPMI PT members are typically medium-sized enterprises, such as restaurants, cafes, freelance design services, and so on. [S26] ## Types of Member Businesses

* Plantation, Agriculture, Forestry, and Fisheries
* Mining
* Chemical Industry, Electronics Industry, Automotive
* Parts Industry, Furniture Industry
* Tourism
* Civil and Mechanical Construction Services
* Consultancy Services
* Procurement Services
* Financial Services
* Digital Services
* Distribution
* Other Services

## List of Chairman of HIPMI

Passage 2:
[S27] | No | Name | Start date | End date |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 1 | Abdul Latief | 1972 | 1973 |
| 2 | Siswono Yudo Husodo | 1973 | 1977 |
| 3 | Aburizal Bakrie | 1977 | 1979 |
| 4 | Pontjo Sutowo | 1979 | 1983 |
| 5 | Agung Laksono | 1983 | 1986 |
| 6 | Sharif Cicip Sutarjo | 1986 | 1989 |
| 7 | Bambang Riyadi Soegomo | 1989 | 1992 |
| 8 | Adi Putra Darmawan Tahir | 1992 | 1995 |
| 9 | Bambang Atmanto Wiyogo | 1995 | 1998 |
| 10 | Hariyadi Budisantoso Sukamdani | 1998 | 2001 |
| 11 | Muhammad Lutfi | 2001 | 2005 |
| 12 | Sandiaga Salahuddin Uno | 2005 | 2008 |
| 13 | Erwin Aksa Mahmud | 2008 | 2011 |
| 14 | Raja Sapta Oktohari | 2011 | 2015 |
| 15 | Bahlil Lahadalia | 2015 | 2019 |
| 16 | Mardani H. [S28] Maming | 2019 | 2022 |
| Plt. [S29] | Eka Sastra | 2022 | 2022 |
| 17 | Akbar Buchari | 2022 | 2025 |


## Structure BPP HIPMI 2022–2025

| NO | NAMA | JABATAN |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **1** | **Akbar Buchari** | **Chairman** |
| 2 | Bobby Nasution | Vice Chairman |
| 3 | Tri Febrianto Damu | Head of Division 1 |
| 4 | Vasko Ruseimy | Head of Division 2 |
| 5 | Elia Nelson Kumaat | Head of Division 3 |
| 6 | Afifuddin Suhaeli Kalla | Head of Division 4 |
| 7 | Mufti Anam | Head of Division 5 |
| 8 | Arie Nanda Djausal | Head of Division 6 |
| 9 | M. [S30] Hadi Nainggolan | Head of Division 7 |
| 10 | Alvin Kennedy | Head of Division 8 |
| 11 | Tri Febriyanto Damu | Head of Division 9 |
| 12 | Muliandy Nasution | Head of Division 10 |
| 13 | Celny Pitasari | Head of Division 11 |
| 14 | M. [S31] Aaron Sampetoding | Head of Division 12 |
| **15** | **Anggawira** | **Secretary General** |
| **16** | **Reynaldo Bryan T. [S32] Allo** | **General Treasurer** |

qa_pairs.question: How does HIPMI's membership criteria, including the distinction between Regular and Extraordinary Members, support its mission of fostering entrepreneurship among youth?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>HIPMI's membership criteria, which categorizes members into Regular (aged 17–40) and Extraordinary (over 41) Members, directly supports its mission of fostering entrepreneurship among youth by focusing on young entrepreneurs while leveraging the expertise of more experienced individuals.<cite>[S15][S16][S17]</cite></statement> <statement>The age limit for Regular Members ensures the organization prioritizes youth, enabling HIPMI to provide targeted resources, training, and networking opportunities to individuals in the critical early stages of their entrepreneurial journeys.<cite>[S7][S16]</cite></statement> <statement>Extraordinary Members, comprising older entrepreneurs, likely contribute mentorship and guidance, creating a knowledge-sharing environment that strengthens the development of younger members and aligns with HIPMI's goal of cultivating a robust entrepreneurial ecosystem.<cite>[S17][S7]</cite></statement>

qa_pairs.thinking:
Okay, let's tackle this question. The user is asking how HIPMI's membership criteria, specifically the distinction between Regular and Extraordinary Members, supports its mission of fostering entrepreneurship among youth. 

First, I need to look through the provided passage to find relevant information. The passage mentions that HIPMI was established to foster entrepreneurship among youth. The membership section says Regular Members are aged 17-40, and those over 41 are Extraordinary Members or Seniors. 

So, the age limit for Regular Members is up to 40, which is definitely young adults. This ensures that the organization focuses on younger individuals who are likely to be starting their careers or businesses. By having a clear age range, HIPMI can target programs and resources towards this demographic. 

The Extraordinary Members are those over 41, which might include experienced entrepreneurs. Their inclusion could provide mentorship opportunities, where seniors can guide the younger members. This mentorship would help the youth gain experience and skills, thereby supporting the mission.

Also, the passage states that membership is open to anyone with a business. This means that both young entrepreneurs and more experienced ones can join, creating a network that fosters collaboration and knowledge sharing. 

I need to check the citations. The relevant sentences are S15 (membership types), S16 (age for Regular), S17 (Extraordinary Members over 41), and S7 (mission to foster entrepreneurship). 

So, the answer should connect the age criteria to targeting youth, and the presence of seniors for mentorship. Each point needs to be cited properly. Let me structure the statements with the correct citations.

qa_pairs.question: What is the duration of the current leadership term of Akbar Buchari, and how does it compare to the terms of previous chairmen in terms of length?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The current leadership term of Akbar Buchari as the Chairman of the Indonesian Young Entrepreneurs Association (HIPMI) is from 2022 to 2025, which spans a duration of three years.<cite>[S8][S27]</cite></statement><statement>Previous chairmen of HIPMI have served terms of varying lengths. For example, Abdul Latief (1972–1973) served 1 year, Siswono Yudo Husodo (1973–1977) served 4 years, and Pontjo Sutowo (1979–1983) also served 4 years. More recently, Mardani H. Maming (2019–2022) served a 3-year term, similar to Akbar Buchari's current term. Thus, Akbar Buchari's 3-year term aligns with some previous chairmen but is shorter than the 4-year terms of leaders like Siswono Yudo Husodo and Pontjo Sutowo.<cite>[S27]</cite></statement>
qa_pairs.chunk:
Passage 1:
[S1] Indonesian Young Entrepreneur Association


# Indonesian Young Entrepreneur Association



**The Indonesian Young Entrepreneurs Association** (Indonesian: Himpunan Pengusaha Muda Indonesia) abbreviated as **HIPMI**, is an independent, non-partisan organization of young Indonesian entrepreneurs engaged in the economic sector. [S2] The organization was founded on June 10, 1972, by several national entrepreneurs including Drs. [S3] Abdul Latief, Ir. [S4] Siswono Yudo Husodo, Teuku Sjahrul, Datuk Hakim Thantawi, Badar Tando, Drs. [S5] Rudy Kairupan, Irawan Djajaatmadja, SH, Hari Sjamsudin Mangaan, Pontjo Sutowo, and Ir. [S6] Mahdi Diah. [S7] The establishment of this organization was driven by the spirit of fostering entrepreneurship among the youth. [S8] On November 23, 2022, Akbar Buchari was elected as the Chairman of the Indonesian Young Entrepreneurs Association (term 2022–2025), succeeding the previous chairman, Mardani H. [S9] Maming. [S10] ## Organizational Structure

The organizational structure of HIPMI exists at both the central and regional levels. [S11] HIPMI has established a Central Executive Board (BPP) headquartered in the capital city, Regional Executive Boards based in the provincial capitals, and Branch Executive Boards based in the regency/city capitals. [S12] To date, HIPMI has a presence in 37 provinces in Indonesia and comprises 354 Branch Executive Boards. [S13] In line with regional autonomy and expansion, HIPMI continues to grow to ensure representation throughout Indonesia. [S14] ## Membership

The organization's regulations establish two types of membership. [S15] Regular Members are those aged 17 – 40 years. [S16] Those who have surpassed the age of 41 are granted the status of Extraordinary Members, commonly referred to as Seniors. [S17] Membership is open to anyone who owns a business. [S18] ## HIPMI University (HIPMI PT)

HIPMI University, established on August 21, 2006, is an autonomous organization initiated by Erwin Aksa, Raja Sapta Oktohari, and Bahlil Lahadalia. [S19] The organization was first inaugurated by Jusuf Kalla, the Vice President of the Republic of Indonesia, and Erwin Aksa, Chairman of HIPMI for the 2008–2011 period. [S20] As its name suggests, HIPMI PT accepts members who are still undergraduate, master's, and doctoral students. [S21] With the presence of HIPMI PT, it is hoped that students can create job opportunities rather than just seeking employment. [S22] HIPMI initiated this organization due to the high unemployment rate in Indonesia. [S23] The organization observed that a significant portion of the unemployed were educated individuals. [S24] Therefore, university students are trained to become Economic Heroes who can improve the quality of human resources mentally, create jobs, and develop businesses effectively. [S25] The types of businesses run by HIPMI PT members are typically medium-sized enterprises, such as restaurants, cafes, freelance design services, and so on. [S26] ## Types of Member Businesses

* Plantation, Agriculture, Forestry, and Fisheries
* Mining
* Chemical Industry, Electronics Industry, Automotive
* Parts Industry, Furniture Industry
* Tourism
* Civil and Mechanical Construction Services
* Consultancy Services
* Procurement Services
* Financial Services
* Digital Services
* Distribution
* Other Services

## List of Chairman of HIPMI

Passage 2:
[S27] | No | Name | Start date | End date |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 1 | Abdul Latief | 1972 | 1973 |

| 9 | Bambang Atmanto Wiyogo | 1995 | 1998 |
| 10 | Hariyadi Budisantoso Sukamdani | 1998 | 2001 |
| 11 | Muhammad Lutfi | 2001 | 2005 |

| 13 | Erwin Aksa Mahmud | 2008 | 2011 |
| 14 | Raja Sapta Oktohari | 2011 | 2015 |
| 15 | Bahlil Lahadalia | 2015 | 2019 |
| 16 | Mardani H. [S28] Maming | 2019 | 2022 |
| Plt. [S29] | Eka Sastra | 2022 | 2022 |
